title: North Temperate Lakes - LTER
text:
The North Temperate Lakes Long-Term Ecological Research (NTL-LTER) program conducts and facilitates long-term ecological research on Wisconsin lakes. Housed on both the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus and at Trout Lake Station, NTL is part of the larger LTER network funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation since 1981.
NTL forecasts are generated in collaboration with scientists from NTL at the UW Center for Limnology (Noah Lottig, Paul Schramm, and Paul Hanson).

Sparkling Lake


The most recent forecast is from 2024-03-28 20:00:00 (Eastern U.S. time).

title: Western Virginia Water Authority
text:
Below are forecasts for three reservoirs managed by the Western Virginia Water Authority (WVWA). The WVWA is the primary supplier of drinking water to the Roanoke, VA region.
Forecasts are developed in partnership with WVWA. More information about past performance at Falling Creek Reservoir can be found in Thomas et al. 2020

Falling Creek ReservoirBeaver Dam ReservoirCarvins Cove Reservoir

title: National Ecological Observatory Network
text:
The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) is a U.S. National Science Foundation-funded project to monitor 81 ecosystems across the U.S. using standardized measurements over the next 30 years. We generate forecasts for the seven lakes that are monitored by NEON. These lakes range from hot humid (Florida) to cold tundra (Alaska) environments.
Forecasts of NEON lakes are contributed to the NEON Ecological Forecasting Challenge, hosted by the Ecological Forecasting Initiative Research Coordination Network. More information about past performance at NEON Lakes can be found in Thomas et al. 2023.

Barco LakeCrampton LakeLittle Rock LakePrairie LakePrairie PotholeSuggs LakeToolik Lake

title: University of Western Australia
text:
Lake Alexandrina is located in South Australia and is monitored by the state water authority (SA Water). The forecasts are generated in collaboration with Matt Hipsey’s research group at the University of Western Australia.

Lake AlexandrinaCanning Weir Pool


The most recent forecast is from 2024-03-28 20:00:00 (Eastern U.S. time).
Experimental forecast for the Lake Alexandrina, developed in collaboration between the Center for Ecosystem Forecasting at Virginia Tech and the Aquatic EcoDynamics Research Group at the University of Western Australia. The top figures show water temperature forecasts for 1 to 35 days into the future for 0.5 m and 5 m depth. The black line shows the median water temperature forecast, with the blue shared area encompassing the 90% predictive intervals. The bottom figure shows the percent chance of the waterbody mixing between 0.5 and 5 m, determined by a 0.1 g/cm3 density gradient.












The most recent forecast is from 2024-03-28 20:00:00 (Eastern U.S. time).
Experimental forecast for the Canning Weir Pool, developed in collaboration between the Center for Ecosystem Forecasting at Virginia Tech and the Aquatic EcoDynamics Research Group at the University of Western Australia. The top figures show water temperature forecasts for 1 to 35 days into the future for 0.5 m and 3.5 m depth. The black line shows the median water temperature forecast, with the blue shared area encompassing the 90% predictive intervals. The bottom figure shows the percent chance of the waterbody mixing between 0.5 and 5 m, determined by a 0.1 g/cm3 density gradient.

title: Dashboard
text:
Welcome to the Forecasting Lake and Reservoir Ecosystems (FLARE) dashboard!
This page was last updated on 2024-03-29
This dashboard provides daily updates to visualize recent water quality forecasts generated across the world using FLARE system. FLARE iterative updates model simulations using real-time data and quantifies uncertainty in forecasts.

FLARE sites






This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation as part of awards CNS-1737424, DBI-1933102, and DBI-1933016​. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

title: Lake Sunapee Protective Association
text:
Below are forecasts for Lake Sunapee, NH. Lake Sunapee is the fifth largest lake in New Hampshire. The forecasts are for the location of the bouy that is maintained by the Lake Sunapee Protective Association (LPSA).
Forecasts are generated in collaboration with the LPSA and Kathleen Weathers from the Cary Institute for Ecosystem Studies.

Lake Sunapee


The most recent forecast is from 2024-03-28 20:00:00 (Eastern U.S. time).





Points represent sensor observations of water temperature. Lines represents the mean prediction from the forecast ensembles, or the most likely outcome.The shaded areas represent the 90% confidence interval of the forecast, or the possible range of outcomes based on the forecast.
